content: The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" designates and provides assistance for high-intensity interstate gang activity areas under Title XV of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. In the "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007," definitions for terms like Governor, high-intensity interstate gang activity area, and State are provided. The Attorney General may designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas for federal assistance based on specific criteria. The Attorney General shall establish criminal street gang enforcement teams in high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, comprising Federal, State, and local law enforcement authorities for coordinated investigation and prosecution of criminal street gangs and offenders. The Attorney General shall establish criminal street gang enforcement teams in high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, comprising Federal, State, and local law enforcement authorities. These teams will receive personnel from other departments, necessary funding for operations, and support for national and regional meetings to ensure effective operation. Each criminal street gang enforcement team established shall consist of agents and officers from various federal agencies, including the FBI, DEA, ATF, and US Marshals Service. The Attorney General considers various agencies and criteria when designating high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, including federal agencies like the FBI, DEA, ATF, US Marshals Service, Department of Homeland Security, Department of Housing and Urban Development, and state and local law enforcement. The Attorney General considers factors such as current and predicted gang crime levels, the relationship between violent crime and gang activity, and the resources allocated by state and local law enforcement agencies to address the gang crime problem. The Attorney General may hire up to 94 additional Assistant U.S. Attorneys to address gang crime activities, considering factors like current crime levels, the impact of federal resources, and other relevant criteria. The Attorney General may hire additional Assistant U.S. Attorneys to address gang crime activities in high-intensity interstate gang areas, with necessary appropriations authorized. SEC. 3. Grants to state and local prosecutors to combat violent crime and protect witnesses and victims. Grants to hire additional prosecutors, fund technology, equipment, and training for accurate identification of gang members and violent offenders. The text chunk discusses the authorization of appropriations for the identification of gang members and violent offenders, as well as funding for technology, equipment, and training for prosecutors to increase successful prosecution of young violent offenders. Authorization of $20,000,000 appropriations for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to establish state-wide crime prevention databases for state and local law enforcement. The Office of Justice Programs will award grants to State and local programs to establish State-wide databases tracking criminals, arrests, prosecutions, and convictions. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose.
